awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Measurement and Modeling of Industrial Control Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Operators of industrial control systems have limited software tools for obtaining situational awareness of their networks and processes. This project seeks to characterize network traffic for a rich variety of industrial control networks.  Because the research community lacks access to (mostly proprietary) data sets from operating control systems, our ability to identify anomalous behavior and protect weaknesses is a concern for critical U.S. infrastructure.  The research team has obtained a collection of network data sets that will allow them to study the performance (and security) properties of various types of industrial control systems, including wastewater treatment, power, and solar energy. By examining the similarities and differences of these data sets, this analysis will yield models of critical infrastructure control system traffic that will aid in anomaly detection and further our understanding of these networks in general.

The project will characterize network flows, and perform deep-packet inspection in a protocol- and process-aware fashion.  The project will develop open-source tools implementing anomaly detection algorithms to be used by researchers and the process control industry. Since the anomaly detection tools are passive, they can ultimately be deployed in the operational environments of industrial partners to help them improve the visibility and understanding of their control networks. This work will be performed in collaboration with researchers in Israel under the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation joint funding program.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on network measurement of industrial control networks. These networks are critical to the operation of various critical infrastructure systems, from power systems to gas and water networks.

Monitoring and protecting Industrial Control Systems (ICS) requires solutions that do not disturb existing operations, which is essential for large-scale systems and, especially, for legacy systems. In this project, we worked to create new tools, algorithms, and software to improve our understanding of how these systems are used in practice, and to better protect them. Our work included the first academic publication studying the SCADA networks in use for an operational bulk power grid.

Our motivation is that to defend the ICS networks of these systems, we need to first understand them. Proposing a security solution based solely on observations from simulations or testbeds is not a practical approach. In this project we created various profiles of real-world systems to help researchers understand these critical infrastructures, and create better models of what is expected, and what is anomalous and potentially dangerous.

Our research acknowledging the support from this grant was accepted and published in 14 peer-reviewed academic conferences. Eight of them acknowledging the original award number CNS-1718848 and six of them acknowledging the new award number CNS-1929406 (when the PI moved to UC Santa Cruz). Four of these publications had acceptance rates close to 15%, representing some of the top venues for publishing research on cybersecurity and network measurements.

Our paper with our international colleagues from Israel was a finalist of the Cybersecurity Games & Confference (CSAW) Applied Research Competition competition in Israel 2018. Our research also won the best presentation award for our paper presented at the International Workshop on Traffic Measurements for Cybersecurity, May 23, 2019.

Two Ph.D. students also graduated with support from this grant. Finally, the software artifacts produced from our research are openly available. 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/21/2023
Modified by: Alvaro A Cardenas
